Scene: A New Jersey Transit train on the way to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan during the morning rush one morning recently.
DEAR DIARY:
Scene: A New Jersey Transit train on the way to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan during the morning rush one morning recently.
Conductor (full volume on the intercom): ''Will the individual doing their nails in the first car please stop! It is making the engineer dizzy!''
Harold N. Krauss (Well, since he put it like that . . . )
Overheard in the checkout line at Staples in Randolph:
First woman: ''In all my years of teaching kindergarten, I've never run into so many cases of separation anxiety.''
Second woman: ''I suppose I'm lucky. By third grade, the kids have adjusted.''
First woman: ''Forget the kids. I'm talking about the parents.''
Audrey Corn
And speaking of the reopening of school, this was overheard during a recent shopping excursion:
Man: ''Kids go back to school yet?''
Woman: ''Wednesday.''
Man: ''Happy Mother's Day.''
Dorothy Leichter
Recently I suffered a bout of intermittent hoarseness that required a trip to the doctor He gave me some throat spray and allergy medicine and sent me home.
When my neighbor, Bill, asked me how the visit went, I told him the doctor said my hoarseness was the result of an overindulgence of sex and alcohol.
(I wish.)
A few days later when I saw Bill in the backyard and asked him how he was doing, he motioned me over and croaked, ''Do you want a cough drop?''
Art Simeone

At a recent recent church picnic for St. Matthew's in Randolph, many of the picnickers were stood in front of the tables while a sermon was delivered, with mothers and fathers holding back their children, who wanted to munch on hot dogs and play.
As the pastor continued to deliver the sermon over a loudspeaker -- mostly in a monotone -- the chatter of nearby tennis players was drowning him out.
Then, as he neared the end, he raised his voice sharply and shouted, ''Let us praise God . . . ''
At that point, totally unaware of his timing, a teenager who was hitting with a tennis instructor missed a shot and shouted in frustration, ''Oh. . . . God!''
Even some of the adult church picnickers snickered.
Dawn D'Aries Challis

One morning I heard much commotion and ''En garde'' coming from my kitchen. When I got there, I saw my 8-month-old Westie (her name is Fitzie) in a fierce tug of war with my 5-year-old daughter's dress, which she happened to be wearing.
''Stop that immediately,'' I hollered.
The dog retreated and my daughter responded, ''It was Fitzie's idea.''
''Oh, please,'' I said. ''Dogs don't think like that.''
''Really,'' my daughter answered. ''Then why are you always saying that dog has a mind of her own?''
Deirdre Flanagan Ward

While enjoying the wonders of the cosmos recently at the Hayden Planetarium, I was seated next to a father and his little boy, about 4 years old, who asked during a quiet mement in the presentation, ''Daddy, are we still on Earf?''
Mary Walling-Roche
